job_title: Counterparty Credit Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Nice office environment; open floor plan. Each employee has a cubby (locker) to place valuables.
cons:
The department teams are arranged in small groups of desks right next to each other and directly across, with no barriers or plexiglass of any kind; very unsafe for COVID. Absolutely no storage or file space at workstations. No telephones on desks. Employees have to communicate via Skype for everything, even IT assistance! No one to call at HR, if you have a problem! No department secretary to help with onboarding! New employees must learn to navigate extremely cumbersome and unfriendly internal systems to process all their own onboarding documents! Also, be prepared to receive upwards of 400 emails (you heard me) every day! That's not an exaggeration! That is an average of the amount of emails you will receive daily, due to all the system generated emails of nearly every department in the bank! These emails will absolutely bury you, leaving you unable to focus on your work. Management simply pretends it isn't a problem, so don't even think of complaining:)

Management schedules department conference calls (sometimes multiple times a day!) tying up employees for hours, lecturing them on not achieving the department's goals, and trying to figure out how to make the employees work faster...Maybe not scheduling a two hour conference call, and tying up 35 people would be a good start?

I worked in the Hedge Fund counterparty risk department, where they had the Archegos Fund blow-up in 2021. I was not there at the time, but it was very evident to me how something like that could have happened there. The entire department is run by managers who are driving blindly, concerned only with process and not actual counterparty risk. They are too concerned with catching the tiny, inconsequential errors that don't matter that they miss the big picture, the ticking time bombs like Archegos! It won't be the last one!

The team leader of my group was not very collegial or approachable. She did not like questions, and would frown on taking notes. I felt like I was walking on egg shells every day! I tried desperately to avoid asking her any questions because she would always have a snarky reply. The other team members were better, but many times were unresponsive. One of the senior managers in the department recruited me for the role, but once I started, he never spoke to me. I would try to arrange a meeting on his calendar, but at the last minute he would just cancel.

If you want to work in a dynamic, vibrant workplace with a lot of interaction with colleagues, don't work there! It is a frightful, dire, depressing place where the toxic corporate culture permeates down through the ranks. They might offer you more money, but don't fall for it...you will regret it! Credit Suisse is not a top tier investment bank (perhaps long ago it once was). It is a failing, dismal, toxic institution with a culture to match.

pros: There simply aren't any Pros. The culture is rotten to the core and (somehow) getting worse. Front page scandal follows front page scandal. It is a mark of true talent to find the worst in every potential situation. That is the one thing that they excel at.

The latest financial shenanigans have cost billions so budgets have been slashed yet again. Yes the typo is deliberate. Turning on a light switch has a three page PPT with accompanying flowchart, and you will have to certify that you did it correctly at least once a month. Most of your working life will be spent on signing off petty processes, writing up your team for the smallest errors, and being investigated because you made a mistake while trying to manage the work of three people and cover for two more who are on sick leave from stress. And they do not believe in pay increases, so if you join, negotiate hard, because that will be it.
